Your explanation on babel is very clear. 
But where does the serve command come from?

response.content:
I was referring to the serve command you can get from npm.  If you have nodejs (and npm) installed just key the following command to install it: 
npm install -g serve
If you don't have nodejs installed, follow the instructions from nodejs.org.
You can also just open up the html file in your browser from the file system.
Let me know if you need any other help.

results.content: This is an amazing course especially for learning to build real-time apps. You get to learn 3 different technologies which are all amazing especially Golang and RethinkDB! I'm not much of a front end guy or even javascript guy I love the backend! Go is an amazing language by far my favorite one its easy to learn and write. RethinkDB is my go to database now! I use to use SQL database such as mysql or postgresql and I always wanted to switch to a nosql db like mongodb but since i started this course i've found that RethinkDB is the best nosql and since it has its own query language its kinda like a sql db too all in one its just amazing! A new school project i'm working on will be using golang and rethinkdb for my backend and maybe vue.js for the front end just to keep it easy and simple :D Great course keep making them especially for Go and Rethink :D

response.content:
Hi John, thanks for your feedback.  
I've always been bothered by screencasts that were slow, had lot's of "um, ah.." etc as I felt my time was being wasted.  In my opinion it's much easier and more pleasant to pause and replay portions of a video to ensure you understand something vs. slogging through a painfully slow course with lot's of useless filler.  
I understand that this style isn't for everyone, but I believe there is a significant amount of students that will appreciate it.
I've tried to be very upfront about the speed of the course (in the course description) and included a lot of free preview (first 8 lectures are free preview) so this would hopefully not come as a surprise.
Best,
James

results.content:
The course was made 3 years ago and it hasn't been updated since then. It's not really outdated, since React or Go haven't changed that much, but React 0.14 and Golang 1.5 (released in 2015) were used and it's been a long time since then.
If you don't know anything about React or Go you'll be lost very quickly; this is not a course to get a good understanding of these technologies, but to get something up and running or have an overview of the whole process.
The pace is too fast (you'll be using the playback rate for sure).
My (good) experience on Udemy up to this point is with courses of Max S. (Nuxt, Flutter, ...) and Todd M. (Golang) and I have to say this course doesn't get that level at all.
If you have basic/mid understanding of React and Golang, it's possible to get useful information but the quality is overpriced at this point in time.
The goal of this course is too ambitious and the content is based on previous knowledge you'll have to get from other specific courses.
As I mentioned, you can still get SOMETHING GOOD from this course, but you've been warned about the downsides.

results.content:
This course assumes prior programming knowledge. It spends no time on teaching beginner basics. Having said that, it's perfect for those with some experience. James covers a lot of ground very quickly, and shows you all the source code required to build a fully functioning app. The best way to grok it all is to type out the code in each video and work through the errors to really get a feel for each technology. This course has really piqued my interested in Golang and its ease of use in creating realtime backends.
Looking forward to more of such high quality courses from James!

I see questions about this that have not received an answer in over a year.  I believe that if Udemy is still selling the class then the author should still support it. results.content:
Great content but hard to grasp as author is delivering them so quickly that you miss a good chunk. ~40 percentage of each lecture is lost in the speed. 

I'm an experienced React/NodeJS developer (5 years), Java (8 years), C++ (5 years). So I'm not new to programming. And I lead a development team in a top 5 investment bank - so not out of touch.

However I'm new to Golang so wanted to learn if I should adopt it for webservers. Watching his course was so hard due to its speed of delivery that I decided to search for the same concepts on the web myself as it was just not viable to keep watching. Which was disappointing as the author had great content to teach. This is a good example how delivery can spoil a great course.

results.content:
Course is pretty good, though for the reactjs section a lot of things are just stated, but not explained, but in the golang section a lot more things are explained in depth.  The reactjs libraries are a little dated and users will need to be careful to use exactly the same versions for the react section. 

There's two "build these yourself" sections which at first seem pretty straight forward, the resulting code revealed in the "lets go over the code" bit added features not yet discussed, and I was very glad that he included the up to date code to download at that moment. I was how ever disappointed that in the second diy section the code was not included. Upon looking up the commit history of the github repo included on the 2nd to last lecture section, I was pleasantly surprised to find a commit history that followed along to each section.  Man, that would of been handy in some of the longer code sections that you couldn't do testing in. 

Instructor also has the habit of covering up the section of code hes talking about, before he finishes explaining  the section of code. Even a second pause between the last word, and the code becoming invisible would of improved the follow and listen. As it stands its better to listen to the entire lecture, and then rewind and pause to read all of the code in the few seconds that it is on screen.

results.content:
This is the absolute WORST video tutorial that I have ever used. Pick another lecturer. Reasons :
1) He talks way too fast, and does not explain why he is doing things to a great enough extent. His whole motto is "cutting the fat from the course", but in reality he blazes through so fast that you can't get a grip on the understanding that you are wanting

2) He doesn't test his code until it is completely done. So, if at the end of 7 lecture videos (yes, 9-16) you get an error and your app doesn't work, you are out of luck. And to make it worse, his github code is not section by section... you only get the code from the very end, which will include extra methods that will give you errors.

Don't waste $40 on this. Thankfully Udemy offers 30 day refunds, but don't waste your time either.

response.content:
Hi Ryan, sorry you didn't like the course.  
This course isn't for everyone, however many people really like the pace and style I use.

I'm very upfront about the pacing and I provide 11 lectures previews so the format should come as no surprise.

One of my primary goals it making courses that don't waist your time... The caveat is you'll likely need to pause and replay some sections of the video to ensure you understand what's going on. 
I believe occasionally replaying a video is a much better option, than having to slog through a course that is painfully slow and long.

Best,
James

results.content:
Right off the bat, I've found myself at odds with the way this instructor is. I really like the pace, you'll find yourself pausing pretty frequently to keep up if you are coding alongside the video. 

The part that I find the most frustrating is this "All setup (Development tools, Database Setup etc) is covered in this course"

But he doesn't really give you the tools, he is using a unix command prompt while much of his class will likely be on PC and either not have this option or not know how to get this option onto their PC. So when he is at the end and says "Just type serve" there is zero explanation there for a PC user. He's cut off a good portion of his students right at video 1.

Then he also has long links that he gives no way of copying or a way to get an updated CDN (it's been 2 years since he posted these or made any edits to his github for this course). I worked through this decently quick myself, but where he is saying it's a course for basically anyone, he's dropped the ball, and has done it quite fast.

results.content: This is my least favorite course on Udemy. The author speaks over top of a prerecorded Screen-Captured video. The author tries to explain things clearly, but the video is played back at an estimated 400% speed. It's impossible to follow along without pausing every few seconds. If you want to simply watch, that's a little easier, but it's still so fast. The whole experience makes me feel like he was constrained to a max time length and was cutting corners. I'm sick of having to pause and rewind just to follow along. I really wish I could have a refund.
